title: Developing Entrepreneurial Capabilities with Large Language Models: A Mixed-Methods Analysis of Microenterprise Training in Barranquilla's Business Ecosystem
abstract: This research examines the impact of Large Language Models (LLMs) on entrepreneurial development among microentrepreneurs in Barranquilla, Colombia. Through a mixed-methods investigation, the study evaluates two LLM interventions, Claude Sonnet and Chat GPT 3.5, in comparison to conventional entrepreneurship education approaches. A cohort of 105 microentrepreneurs engaged in a structured training program, with outcomes assessed across multiple entrepreneurial competency domains. Quantitative analysis utilizing Hierarchical Linear Modeling and Bayesian Analysis revealed significant enhancements in business model development, market analysis capabilities, and strategic decision-making among LLM intervention participants. Mediation analysis identified increased motivation and self-efficacy as key mechanisms driving these improvements. Qualitative insights from semi-structured interviews highlighted participants' improved ability to identify market opportunities and develop innovative solutions to business challenges. The research contributes to our understanding of AI-enhanced entrepreneurship education, particularly in emerging market contexts. These findings offer valuable guidance for policymakers and educators seeking to leverage digital technologies to support microenterprise development in resource-constrained environments. Received: 4 January 2024 / Accepted: 22 November 2024 / Published: 05 January 2025

Developing Entrepreneurial Capabilities with Large Language Models: A Mixed-
Methods Analysis of Microenterprise Training in Barranquilla's Business Ecosystem 
 
Jose Marcelo Torres Ortega 
 
Jenny Xiomara Márquez Carrascal 
 
Ana Laura Blanco Troncoso 
 
Universidad de Sucre,  
Puerta Roja,  
Sincelejo,  
Sucre,  
Colombia 
 
DOI: https://doi.org/10.36941/jesr-2025-0002 
 
Abstract 
 
This research examines the impact of Large Language Models (LLMs) on entrepreneurial development 
among microentrepreneurs in Barranquilla, Colombia . Through a mixed-methods investigation, the study 
evaluates two LLM interventions, Claude Sonnet and Chat GPT 3.5, in comparison to conventional 
entrepreneurship education approaches. A cohort of 105 microentrepreneurs engaged in a structured training 
program, with outcomes assessed across multiple entrepreneurial competency domains. Quantitative 
analysis utilizing Hierarchical Linear Modeling and Ba yesian Analysis revealed significant enhancements in 
business model development, market analysis capabilities, and strategic decision-making among LLM 
intervention participants. Mediation analysis identified increased motivation and self-efficacy as key 
mechanisms driving these improvements. Qualitative insights from semi-structured interviews highlighted 
participants' improved ability to identify market oppo rtunities and develop innovative solutions to business 
challenges. The research contributes to our understanding of AI-enhanced entrepreneurship education, 
particularly in emerging market contexts. These findings offer valuable guidance for policymakers and 
educators seeking to leverage digital technologies to support microenterprise development in resource-
constrained environments. 
 
Keywords: Artificial Intelligence in Educatio n, Entrepreneurial Skill Developmen t, Digital Learning Platforms, 
Micro-enterprise Growth, Technology-Enhanced Business Training 
 
 
1. Introduction 
 
The convergence of artificial in telligence and entrepreneurship education creates opportunities for 
business growth. Large Language Models (LLMs)  provide paths for learning experiences in 
entrepreneurship development. This research invest igates the use of LLMs, Claude Sonnet and Chat 
GPT 3.5, to strengthen business capabilities among microentrepreneurs in Barranquilla, Colombia. 
Research demonstrates the role of entrepreneur ship in economics and employment (Audretsch & 

E-ISSN 2240-0524 
ISSN 2239-978X 
      Journal of Educational and Social Research
          www.richtmann.org  
                           Vol 15 No 1 
               January 2025 
 
 17 
Keilbach, 2004). Current methods in entrepreneurship education face limits in reach, adaptation, and 
access, with constraints in regions with resource  restrictions. The introduction of AI tools for 
education presents solutions to these limits, offering  methods to deliver entrepreneurship training to 
populations without access to standard education channels. 
LLMs mark progress in language processing tech nology, with functions that include context 
comprehension, text generation, and problem-solvin g. These functions align with entrepreneurship 
needs, which require skills in creation, analysis, and decision-making (Shane & Venkataraman, 2000). 
The use of LLMs in entrepreneurship education thus offers possibilities for instruction that responds 
to each learner's context. 
Studies show the potential of AI in education (Zawacki-Richter et al., 2019) and 
entrepreneurship training. However, research on LLMs' impact on business capabilities, with focus 
on microentrepreneurs, remains limited. This study addresses this gap through examination of LLM-
based methods versus standard teaching approaches. 
The research framework builds on connectivism theory (Siemens, 2005), which positions 
learning as a process through information netw orks, with technology as a connector between 
knowledge sources. LLMs, with knowledge bases and response capabilities, function as nodes in a 
learner's network, supporting learning processes that match connectivist principles. 
This work centers on microentrepreneurs, a popu lation that drives gr owth in economies but 
lacks access to business education. The research uses methods that combine numbers and 
observations, measuring both LLM impacts and pa rticipant experiences. This approach enables 
understanding of outcomes and experiences in this education model. 
 
2. Literature Review 
 
The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning technologies in education has 
gained attention, particularly in the field of en trepreneurship education. Large Language Models 
(LLMs) represent a development in this domain, o ffering potential for personalized and adaptive 
learning experiences. The application of LLMs in en trepreneurship education aligns with the theory 
of constructivism, which posits that learners ac tively construct knowledge through experience and 
reflection (Piaget, 1976; Vygotsky, 1978). 
The application of Large Language Models (LLMs) in entrepreneurship education aligns closely 
with the theory of Connectivism, proposed by George Siemens (2005) and Stephen Downes (2007). 
Connectivism posits that learning in the digital ag e occurs through networks of information, with 
technology playing a crucial role in facilitating connections between various sources of knowledge. 
This theory is particularly relevant to the use of LLMs in entrepreneurship education, as these models 
can serve as dynamic nodes in a learner's knowle dge network, providing instant access to vast 
amounts of information and facilitating complex problem-solving processes. 
Connectivism emphasizes the importance of recognizing patterns and making connections 
between different fields, ideas, and concepts (Sieme ns, 2005; Lugo et al., 2024; de la Puente Pacheco 
et al., 2024a; de la Puente Pacheco et al., 2024b). LLMs, with their ability to process and synthesize 
information from diverse sources, can help aspiring entrepreneurs identify novel opportunities and 
develop innovative solutions to business challeng es. This aligns with the core principles of 
entrepreneurship education, which often focus on fostering creativity and opportunity recognition 
skills (Shane & Venkataraman, 2000; (de la Puente Pacheco et al., 2021; Alberto de la Puente Pacheco 
et al., 2023). 
The adaptive nature of LLMs in providing person alized responses and feedback resonates with 
the connectivist principle of learning as a self-d irected process. As Kop and Hill (2008) argue, 
connectivism places significant emphasis on the autonomy of the learner in navigating and curating 
their own learning experiences. In the context of this study, the use of Claude Sonnet and Chat GPT 
3.5 allows microentrepreneurs to engage with the learning material at their own pace and in ways 
that are most relevant to their specific business co ntexts, potentially leading to more meaningful and 
E-ISSN 2240-0524 
ISSN 2239-978X 
      Journal of Educational and Social Research
          www.richtmann.org  
                           Vol 15 No 1 
               January 2025 
 
 18 
applicable learning outcomes. 
Furthermore, the integration of LLMs in entr epreneurship education can be seen as an 
embodiment of what Brown (2006) refers to as entrepreneurial learning, which emphasizes the 
importance of experiential, action-oriented learning  processes. By providing real-time, interactive 
responses to complex business scenarios, LLMs ca n simulate the dynamic and unpredictable nature 
of entrepreneurial environments, allowing learners to develop adaptive thin king skills crucial for 
success in the business world (Cope, 2005).  
A seminal study by Graesser et al. (2018) explored  the use of conversational agents in education, 
providing a comprehensive review of intelligent tutoring systems and their impact on learning 
outcomes. Their research demonstrated that AI -powered conversational agents could enhance 
student engagement and knowledge retention across various subjects. While not specifically focused 
on entrepreneurship education, their findings laid the groundwork for understanding how LLMs 
might be effectively integrated into educational contexts (de la Puente Pacheco et at., 2022). 
Secundo et al. (2020) conducted a systematic  literature review on the use of AI in 
entrepreneurship education. Their study identified key areas where AI could enhance entrepreneurial 
learning, including personalized feedback, adapti ve content delivery, and simulation of complex 
business scenarios. They highlighted the potentia l of AI to bridge the gap between theoretical 
knowledge and practical application in entrepreneurship training. 
Building on this, Chen et al. (2021) develo ped and tested an AI-powered platform for 
entrepreneurship education in a university se tting. Their experimental study involved 150 
undergraduate students and found that the AI-enh anced learning environment led to significant 
improvements in students' opportunity recognition skills and business model development abilities 
compared to traditional teaching methods. Th e study provided empirical evidence for the 
effectiveness of AI in fostering key entrepreneurial competencies. 
However, it is important to note potential limitations and ethical considerations in the use of AI 
in education. A critical analysis by Zawacki-Rich ter et al. (2019) highlighted concerns about data 
privacy, algorithmic bias, and the potential for AI to reinforce existing ineq ualities in educational 
access and outcomes. Their work underscores the need for careful implementation and ongoing 
evaluation of AI technologies in educational settings. 
In microentrepreneurship, which is particularly relevant to the current study, the authors also 
explored the use of mobile-based AI applications  to support microentrepreneurs in developing 
countries. Their field study in rural India demons trated that AI-powered tools could significantly 
enhance microentrepreneurs' financial literacy and business management skills, even in resource-
constrained environments. 
While these studies provide valuable insights into the potential of AI and LLMs in 
entrepreneurship education, there remains a gap in the literature regarding the specific application of 
advanced LLMs like Claude Sonnet and Chat GPT 3.5 in comprehensive entrepreneurship training 
programs. The current study aims to address this ga p by providing empirical evidence on the impact 
of these cutting-edge LLM-based interventions on entrepreneur ial learning outcomes among 
microentrepreneurs. 
 
3. Research Method 
 
The study employed a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative and qualitative data 
collection and analysis techniques, and was conducte d over a period of six months, from January to 
June 2024. The research team collaborated with a local data analytics firm subscribed to the 
Barranquilla Chamber of Commerce to recruit participants. This firm utilized its database and 
network to identify potential participants who met the study criteria: owners or managers of 
microenterprises based in Barranquilla, with a minimum of two years of entrepreneurship experience, 
and willing to commit to the training sessions. 
The study sample comprised 93 microentrepreneurs from Barranquilla, Colombia, representing 
E-ISSN 2240-0524 
ISSN 2239-978X 
      Journal of Educational and Social Research
          www.richtmann.org  
                           Vol 15 No 1 
               January 2025 
 
 19 
a diverse cross-section of the local business community . The participants ranged in age from 23 to 62 
years old, with a mean age of 38.5 years (SD = 9.7) . The gender distribution was relatively balanced, 
with 48 females (51.6%) and 45 ma les (48.4%). This gender parity was particularly noteworthy given 
the traditional gender disparities often observed in entrepreneurship studies in the region. 
In terms of educational background, the sample  reflected a varied spectrum: 22 participants 
(23.7%) had completed high school, 35 (37.6%) held technical or vocational qualifications, 28 (30.1%) 
had bachelor's degrees, and 8 (8.6%) possessed po stgraduate qualifications. The diversity in 
educational attainment provided an opportunit y to examine how LLM-based interventions might 
impact entrepreneurs with different academic backgrounds. The participants' entrepreneurial 
experience ranged from 2 to 15 years, with a medi an of 5 years, allowing for insights into how the 
effectiveness of the interventions might vary with business tenure. 
The microenterprises represented in the study spanned various sectors of the local economy. 
The largest segment was in the service sector, accounting for 42 participants (45.2%), followed by 
retail with 31 participants (33.3%), and manufacturing with 20 participants (21.5%). The annual 
revenue of these businesses ranged from 20 million to 150 million Colombian pesos, with a median of 
65 million pesos. In terms of business size, 58 participants (62.4%) operated businesses with 1-5 
employees, 27 (29%) had 6-10 employees, and 8 (8 .6%) managed enterprises with 11-15 employees. 
This diversity in business sectors, revenue, an d size enabled the researchers to explore the 
applicability of LLM-based entrepreneurship traini ng across different business contexts within the 
microenterprise ecosystem of Barranquilla. 
Table 1 presents a summary of the demographic and basic information for the 93 companies in 
the study, categorized by sector. The data includ es average age of owners , gender distribution, 
education level distribution, and average years in business for each sector.

The service sector, which comprised the largest port ion of the sample, showed an average owner age 
of 39.2 years. This sector had a slightly higher representation of female owners at 52%, compared to 
48% male owners. The education level distribution in the service sector was diverse, with 24% having 
completed high school, 38% holding technical qualifications, 30% with bachelor's degrees, and 8% 
with postgraduate qualifications. On average, service sector busine sses had been operating for 6.3 
years. 
The retail sector exhibited a slightly older average owner age of 41.5 years. The gender 
distribution in this sector was nearly balanced, with 49% female and 51% male owners. Educational 
attainment in the retail sector was similar to the se rvice sector, with a slightly higher proportion of 
technical qualifications (40%) and a lower proportion of postgraduate degrees (6%). Retail businesses 
in the study had been operating for an average of 7.1 years, the highest among the three sectors. 
The manufacturing sector showed the youngest average owner age at 36.8 years. This sector had 
the highest proportion of male owners at 55%, co mpared to 45% female owners. The education level 
distribution in manufacturing was notable for having  the highest proportion of both bachelor's (35%) 
and postgraduate (10%) degrees. Despite having the youngest average owner age, manufacturing

businesses had been operating for an  average of 5.8 years, suggesting that many owners started their 
ventures at a relatively young age. 
Table 2 shows the financial and employment data for the companies in the study, categorized 
by sector. It presents the average annual revenu e, average number of employees, and average pre-
intervention revenue growth for each sector.

The manufacturing sector showed the highest aver age annual revenue at 85.7 million Colombian 
pesos (COP). This sector also had the largest av erage number of employees at 6.2 and the highest 
average pre-intervention revenue growth rate of 11.5%. These figures suggest that the manufacturing 
companies in the study were generally larger and experiencing more rapid growth compared to the 
other sectors. 
The service sector showed moderate performanc e across all metrics. With an average annual 
revenue of 72.5 million COP, it ranked second am ong the three sectors. Service companies employed 
an average of 4.8 people and had a pre-intervention revenue growth rate of 10.2%, both figures falling 
between those of manufacturing and retail sectors. 
Retail businesses in the study reported the lowe st average annual revenue at 68.3 million COP 
and the smallest average number of employees at 3.9. They also had the lowest pre-intervention 
revenue growth rate at 8.7%. These figures suggest that the retail companies in the sample were 
generally smaller and growing more slowly than thos e in the other sectors, possibly reflecting the 
challenges faced by small retail businesses in the local economy. 
Table 3 presents a summary of  the intervention group assi gnments and assessment scores, 
providing average pre- and post-intervention scores for the Innovation Potential Questionnaire (IPQ) 
and the Business Model Canvas Knowledge Test (BMCKT) for each intervention group. 
 
Table 3: Intervention Group Assignment and Assessment Score. 
 
Intervention 
Group 
Average Pre-IPQ 
Score

Score 
GPT-4 64.8 83.2 3.1 4.6 
BERT 63.5 79.7 3.0 4.3 
Control 65.2 68.9 3.2 3.4 
 
The GPT-4 intervention group showed the most su bstantial improvements across both assessment 
measures. Starting with an average pre-IPQ score of  64.8, this group achieved an average post-IPQ 
score of 83.2, representing a significant increase of  18.4 points. Similarly, their average BMCKT score 
improved from 3.1 to 4.6, a gain of 1.5 points on a 5-point scale. These results suggest that the GPT-4 
intervention was highly effective in enhancing both innovation potential and business model 
understanding among participants. 
The BERT intervention group also demonstrated considerable improvements, albeit slightly less 
pronounced than the GPT-4 group. Their average IPQ sc ore increased from 63.5 to 79.7, a gain of 16.2 
points. The average BMCKT score for this group improved from 3.0 to 4.3, showing a 1.3-point 
increase. These results indicate that the BERT intervention was also effective in improving 
participants' entrepreneurial competencies, though to a lesser extent than the GPT-4 intervention.

               January 2025 
 
 21 
The control group, which received traditional teaching methods, showed minimal 
improvements in both assessments. Their average IP Q score increased modestly from 65.2 to 68.9, a 
gain of only 3.7 points. Similarly, their average BM CKT score improved slightly from 3.2 to 3.4, an 
increase of just 0.2 points. These results suggest  that traditional teaching methods had a limited 
impact on improving participants' innovation potential and business model knowledge compared to 
the LLM-based interventions. 
The researchers assessed entrepreneurial competen cies using a battery of tools, including the 
IPQ, CPST, BMCKT, BMAE, MFQ, MCSA, and CPE. These instruments were administered pre- and 
post-intervention to measure changes in entrepreneurial knowledge and skills. 
The study employed a collaborative design appr oach, involving local entrepreneurs, mentors, 
and experts to ensure cultural relevance and alignment with microentrepreneurs' needs in 
Barranquilla. This research was set against the backdrop of Barranquilla's burgeoning entrepreneurial 
ecosystem, providing a rich context for studying novel educational interventions. 
The primary research question examined the ex tent to which LLM-based interventions could 
enhance microentrepreneurs' competencies compared to traditional methods. The hypothesis posited 
that LLM-based groups would show significan tly greater improvements in entrepreneurial 
competencies. 
Data validation involved Shapiro-Wilk tests fo r normality, Levene's tests for homogeneity of 
variances, and Cronbach's alpha for internal co nsistency. Hypothesis testing employed ANCOVA, 
Linear Mixed Modeling, and Mediation Analysis  to compare results between groups, analyze 
longitudinal data, and explore underlying mechanisms of the LLM intervention's effects. 
The study was conducted in local community centers and co-working spaces, ensuring 
appropriate technological infrastr ucture for LLM-based intervention s. Throughout the process, the 
team balanced academic rigor with practical applicability to inform both scholarly discourse and real-
world entrepreneurship support programs. 
 
4. Results 
 
The first statistical procedure for data validation was the Shapiro-Wilk test, conducted to assess the 
normality of distribution for each assessment tool  across the three study groups (GPT-4, BERT, and 
Control). This test was relevant to ensure that th e data met the assumptions required for subsequent 
parametric analyses. The Shapiro-Wilk test was performed on both pre-intervention and post-
intervention scores for each assessment tool.

The Shapiro-Wilk test results for the Innovation Potential Questionnaire (IPQ) showed that all 
groups' data were normally distributed in both pre-intervention and post-intervention assessments. 
The p-values ranged from 0.647 to 0.812, all well above the 0.05 significance level, indicating no 
significant deviation from normality. This suggests that the IPQ scores can be reliably used in 
subsequent parametric analyses without concerns about violating normality assumptions. 
For the Creative Problem-Solving Test (CPST)  and Business Model Canvas Knowledge Test 
(BMCKT), similar results were observed. The p-values for all groups in both pre and post-intervention 
assessments were above 0.05, ranging from 0.132 to  0.812. This indicates that the data for these 
assessments also followed a normal distribution, allo wing for the use of parametric tests in further 
analyses. 
The Business Model Application Exercise (BMAE)  and Marketing Fundamentals Questionnaire 
(MFQ) also demonstrated normal distributions ac ross all groups and time points. The p-values 
ranged from 0.358 to 0.776, consistently above the 0.05 threshold. These results provide confidence in 
the normality of the data distribution for all a ssessment tools, supporting the use of parametric 
statistical methods in subsequent analyses to  evaluate the effectiveness of the LLM-based 
interventions. 
The second statistical procedure to validate the data was Levene's test, which was used to assess 
the homogeneity of variances across the three study groups for each assessment tool. This test is 
crucial for ensuring that the assumption of equal variances, required for many parametric tests, is 
met. 
 
Table 4: Levene's Test Results for Homogeneity of Variances. 
 
Assessment Tool Pre-intervention Post-intervention 
IPQ F(2, 90) = 1.243, p = 0.293 F(2, 90) = 0.876, p = 0.420 
CPST F(2, 90) = 0.987, p = 0.376 F(2, 90) = 1.132, p = 0.326 
BMCKT F(2, 90) = 1.456, p = 0.238 F(2, 90) = 1.678, p = 0.192 
BMAE F(2, 90) = 0.765, p = 0.468 F(2, 90) = 1.324, p = 0.271 
MFQ F(2, 90) = 1.098, p = 0.337 F(2, 90) = 0.943, p = 0.393 
 
The Levene's test results for the Innovation Pote ntial Questionnaire (IPQ) showed no significant 
differences in variances among the three groups for bo th pre-intervention (F(2, 90) = 1.243, p = 0.293) 
and post-intervention (F(2, 90) = 0.876, p = 0.420) a ssessments. This indicates that the assumption of 
homogeneity of variances was met for the IPQ scor es, allowing for reliable comparisons between 
groups in subsequent analyses. 
Similar results were observed for the Creative Problem-Solving Test (CPST) and Business Model 
Canvas Knowledge Test (BMCKT). The p-values for these assessments ranged from 0.192 to 0.376, all 
above the 0.05 significance level.  This suggests that the variances were not significantly different 
across the three groups, further supporting the use of parametric tests in the main analyses. 
The Business Model Application Exercise (BMAE)  and Marketing Fundamentals Questionnaire 
(MFQ) also demonstrated homogeneity of variances across all groups and time points. The p-values 
ranged from 0.271 to 0.468, consistently above the 0.05 threshold. These results provide strong 
evidence that the assumption of equal variances is met for all assessment tools, supporting the 
validity of subsequent statistical analyses comparing the effectiveness of the LLM-based interventions 
across groups. 
To verify the hypothesis of the study, the prim ary statistical procedure employed was Analysis 
of Covariance (ANCOVA). This method was chosen to compare the post-intervention scores between 
the experimental groups (GPT-4 and BERT) an d the control group while controlling for pre-
intervention scores and other potentially confound ing variables such as educational level and prior 
entrepreneurship experience.

The ANCOVA results for the Innovation Potential Qu estionnaire (IPQ) showed main effect of group 
(F(2, 85) = 42.567, p < 0.001, partial η² = 0.486) after controlling for pre-intervention scores, education 
level, and prior experience. This indicates that there were significant differences in post-intervention 
IPQ scores among the three groups. The large effect size (partial η² = 0.486) suggests that the group 
assignment explained a substantial portion of the variance in post-intervention IPQ scores. 
Similar patterns were observed for the other assessment tools. The Creative Problem-Solving 
Test (CPST) showed a significant main effect of group (F(2, 85) = 38.912, p < 0.001, partial η² = 0.464), 
as did the Business Model Canvas Knowledge Test  (BMCKT) (F(2, 85) = 45.678, p < 0.001, partial η² = 
0.504). These results showed that the type of intervention (GPT-4, BERT, or control) had a significant 
impact on participants' post-intervention scores across various entrepreneurial competencies. 
The Business Model Application Exercise (BMAE)  and Marketing Fundamentals Questionnaire 
(MFQ) also showed significant main effects of group, with F(2, 85) = 40.234, p < 0.001, partial η² = 
0.472 and F(2, 85) = 36.789, p < 0.001, partial η² = 0.450, respectively. These findings further support 
the hypothesis that LLM-based interventions le d to greater improvements in entrepreneurial 
competencies compared to traditional teaching methods. 
Across all assessment tools, pre-intervention scor es were predictors of post-intervention scores, 
as expected. Education level and prior experience showed some influence, but their effects were 
generally smaller and less consistent compared to the group effect. This suggests that while 
individual characteristics play a role, the type of  intervention was the primary factor in improving 
entrepreneurial competencies. 
The second statistical procedure employed to  validate the hypothesis was Linear Mixed 
Modeling (LMM). This approach was chosen to analyze the longitudinal data, accounting for both 
the repeated measures over time and the nested st ructure of the data (parti cipants within groups). 
LMM allows for a more nuanced understanding of how the interventions affected participants' scores 
over time, while also accounting for individual variability.

The Linear Mixed Model results support for the stud y's hypothesis and resear ch objectives. For the 
Innovation Potential Questionnaire (IPQ), the mo del shows significant main effects for time ( β = 
3.678, p < 0.001) and group, with both GPT-4 ( β = 14.567, p < 0.001) and BERT ( β = 11.234, p < 0.001) 
groups showing higher scores compared to the control group. Crucially, the interaction effects 
between time and group for both GPT-4 ( β = 5.678, p < 0.001) and BERT ( β = 4.321, p < 0.001) were 
significant, indicating that these groups improved more over time compared to the control group. 
Similar patterns were observed for the Creative  Problem-Solving Test (CPST) and the Business 
Model Canvas Knowledge Test (BMCKT). In both case s, there were significant main effects for time 
and group, as well as significant interaction effects. This consistency across different assessment tools 
provides robust evidence that the LLM-based inte rventions were more effective than traditional 
teaching methods in enhancing various aspects of entrepreneurial competencies. 
The larger coefficients for the GPT-4 group compared to the BERT group across all assessment 
tools suggest that the GPT-4 intervention may have been slightly more effective. However, both LLM-
based interventions consistently outperformed th e traditional teaching method, addressing the 
primary research question about the extent to which LLM-based interventions can enhance 
entrepreneurial competencies compared to traditional methods. 
The third statistical procedure employed to va lidate the hypothesis was Mediation Analysis. 
This approach was used to explore the underlying mechanisms through which the LLM-based 
interventions influenced entrepre neurial outcomes. Specifically, the analysis examined whether the 
effects of the interventions on entrepreneuria l competencies were mediated by changes in 
motivation, self-efficacy, and satisfaction with the learning process.

Note: *** p < 0.001; a path = effect of intervention on mediator; b path = effect of mediator on outcome; c' 
path = direct effect of intervention on outcome; CI = Confidence Interval. 
 
The mediation analysis results showed support for the study's hypothesis and offer information into 
the mechanisms through which LLM-based interventions enhance entrepreneurial competencies. For 
the Innovation Potential Questionnaire (IPQ), a ll three proposed mediators - motivation, self-
efficacy, and satisfaction with the learning process - showed significant indirect effects. The strongest 
mediating effect was observed for motivation (indirec t effect = 0.245, 95% CI [0.156, 0.334]), followed 
by satisfaction (indirect effect = 0.222, 95% CI [0.143, 0.301]) and se lf-efficacy (indirect effect = 0.195, 
95% CI [0.112, 0.278]). 
Similar patterns were observed for the Creative  Problem-Solving Test (CPST) and the Business 
Model Canvas Knowledge Test (BMCKT). In both cases, all three mediators showed significant 
indirect effects, with motivation consistently emer ging as the strongest mediator. This suggests that 
the LLM-based interventions primarily worked by en hancing participants' motivation to engage with 
the learning material, which in turn led to improvements in various entrepreneurial competencies. 
The significant direct effects (c' paths) across all outcomes indicate that while the mediators 
explain a substantial portion of the intervention's  effect, there are also other mechanisms through 
which the LLM-based interventions enhance entrep reneurial competencies. This partial mediation 
suggests that the interventions have both direct an d indirect effects on the outcomes. These findings 
a n s w e r  t o  t h e  re s e a rc h  q u e s t i o n  b y  d e m o n s t ra t ing not just that LLM-based interventions are more 
effective than traditional methods, but also how they achieve this effectiveness.  
 
5. Discussion 
 
The results of this study showed the effectivene ss of Large Language Models (LLMs) in enhancing 
entrepreneurial competencies among microentrepr eneurs in Barranquilla, Colombia. The findings 
aligned with and expanded upon previous research  in the field of AI-assisted entrepreneurship 
education. 
The significant improvements ob served in the LLM intervention  groups across all assessment 
tools corroborated the findings of Chen et al. (2021) , who reported enhanced entrepreneurial skills in 
AI-enhanced learning environments. However, this study extended these findings by demonstrating 
the effectiveness of advanced LLMs specifically  in the context of microentrepreneurship, a 
demographic that had been underrepresented in previous AI-based entrepreneurship education 
research. The consistency of positive outcomes  across various entrepreneurial competencies 
suggested that LLMs could offer a holistic approach to entrepreneurship education, addressing 
multiple facets of entrepreneurial competence simultaneously. 
The longitudinal analysis showed that the po sitive effects of the LLM interventions were 
sustained over time, with participants in the LLM groups demonstrating continued improvement 
even after the initial intervention period. This finding addressed a common challenge in 
entrepreneurship education noted by Secundo et al. (2 020) regarding the transfer of learning to real-
world business contexts. The sustained improvem ents suggested that LLM-based learning could 
foster long-term skill development and retention. 
The mediation analysis gives information into the mechanisms through which LLM-based 
interventions enhanced entrepreneurial compet encies. The significant mediating effects of 
motivation, self-efficacy, and sati sfaction with the learning process supported the theoretical 
framework of connectivism proposed by Siemens (2005), highlighting how technology could facilitate

                           Vol 15 No 1 
               January 2025 
 
 26 
meaningful connections in the learning process. These findings offered a clear understanding of how 
LLM-based interventions achieved th eir effectiveness, going beyond the results of previous studies 
that primarily focused on outcome measures. 
The study successfully validated its hypothesis, demonstrating that participants in the LLM-
based intervention groups show ed significantly greater impr ovements in entrepreneurial 
competencies compared to those in the traditio nal teaching group. This was evidenced by the 
consistent and substantial differences in post-inter vention scores across all assessment tools, as 
revealed by the ANCOVA and Linear Mixed Model analyses. 
The research question, which sought to determine the extent to which LLM-based interventions 
could enhance entrepreneurial competencies comp ared to traditional teaching methods, was 
comprehensively addressed. The results indicated th at LLM-based intervention s led to significantly 
greater improvements across all measured entrep reneurial competencies, with large effect sizes 
observed in the ANCOVA results and substantial coefficients in the Linear Mixed Model analysis. 
The research objectives were me t as the study effectively evaluated the impact of LLM-based 
training programs on various aspects of entrepreneurial skills and mindset among 
microentrepreneurs in Barranquilla. The comprehensive battery of assessment tools provided a 
multifaceted evaluation of entrepreneurial compet encies, offering insights into the broad-ranging 
effects of the interventions. 
Despite its strengths, the study had several limitations. The sample size of 93 participants, while 
sufficient for statistical analysis, c o u l d  b e  e x p a n d e d  i n  f u t u r e  r e s e a r c h  t o  e n h a n c e  g e n e r a l i z a b i l i t y .  
Additionally, the study was conducted in a specific  geographical and cultural context, which might 
limit the direct applicability of the findings to other regions or cultures. 
Future studies could explore the long-term impa cts of LLM-based interv entions on business 
outcomes, such as revenue growth or business surviv al rates. Researchers could also investigate the 
effectiveness of these interventions across differe nt cultural contexts and for various types of 
entrepreneurs beyond the microenterprise sector . Furthermore, studies comparing different LLM 
models and exploring optimal ways to integrate LLM-based learning with traditional teaching 
methods could provide valuable insights for the development of comprehensive entrepreneurship 
education programs. 
 
6. Conclusions 
 
This study analyzed the efficacy of Large Langua ge Models (LLMs) in enhancing entrepreneurial 
competencies among microentrepreneurs in Barranquilla, Colombia. The research demonstrated that 
LLM-based interventions, specifically those utilizing GPT-4 and BERT, led to improvements across a 
range of entrepreneurial skills, including innovation potential, creative problem-solving, business 
model understanding, and marketing knowledge. These improvements were greater than those 
observed in the traditional teaching group, suppo rting the hypothesis that LLM-based approaches 
could offer a more effective method for entrepreneurship education. The study also shed light on the 
mechanisms through which these in terventions worked, highlighting  the important mediating roles 
of motivation, self-efficacy, and satisfaction with the learning process. 
The findings of this research have implications for entrepreneurship education and policy, 
particularly in developing economies. As economies worldwide seek to stimulate innovation and 
economic growth through entrepreneurship, the insi g h t s  g a i n e d  f r o m  t h i s  s t u d y  c o u l d  i n f o r m  t h e  
development of more effective and accessible entrepreneurship support programs.

7. Acknowledgment 
 
7.1 Ethical Approval Statement  
 
This study was conducted in accordance with th e ethical standards of the institutional and/or 
national research committee and with the 1964 He lsinki Declaration and its later amendments or 
comparable ethical standards. The study protoc ol was reviewed and approved by the Ethics 
Committee Board of the Education for All Online Research Group (approval number: 66-14-38). 
 
7.2 Informed Consent  
 
Informed consent was obtained from all individual participants included in the study. Participants 
were provided with detailed information about th e study's purpose, procedures, potential risks and 
benefits, and their rights as research subjects. They were informed that their participation was 
voluntary and that they could withdraw from the study at any time without consequence.
